article: The beginning of a Frank Sinatra song drifted across the dance floor and I knew my dad would call out and request that, which for most people is very _ .   As he walked towards me to ask for the first _ , I could see there were38 _ in his eyes .I grasped the side of my chair, _ myself up with my arms ,and grabbed the two metal sticks which keep me _ as I stood to take his hand.   It took all my will to hold back my own tears and inside a voice kept _ : "Don't fall over ,Martine." We grabbed each other and in some way shuffled out a dance for the whole of the song.   For my dad, it was a turning point. He had _ his friends on his 70th birthday he would lead his daughter in the first dance, _ he had done so many times before .Almost a year after the suicide bomb on the London Underground train which blew _ both my legs above the knee ,I had managed to realize his _ .Like so much that has happened over the last 12 months, there was something _ about the moment.   Today, on July 1, as I face the first anniversary of the terrorist _ , I am preparing to leave the country for a while. I know I _ be celebrating the fact that I am alive, _ I do not feel able to remain in London for the event.   Psychologically, I am a different person. I am very body conscious. When I go out I am _ that children will make fun of me on my artificial legs. In my wheelchair I cover my lower half with a blanket in case what remains of my body draws _ glances.   Despite my brave claims of what I would do when I left the hospital in March ,the reality is that I will _ be able to do many things .I thought I would be able to wear my artificial legs all day ,to run ,to go out alone. But that is just not possible.   I keep asking myself, _ does it become normal? Is this normal now?
